title: 110_hr1163
content: The Act may be cited as the "Stop Obesity in Schools Act of 2007". The Congress finds that a significant percentage of American adults and children are overweight or obese, with a notable increase in obesity rates among children and adolescents over the past few decades. Overweight young people are at risk for various health issues, including heart disease, bone and joint problems, sleep apnea, and psychological challenges. According to the Department of Health and Human Services, obesity-related illnesses cost the nation $117 billion per year, with $61 billion in direct medical costs and $56 billion in indirect costs. A report by Trust for America's Health highlights the lack of a national strategy to address the obesity crisis in the United States. The national strategy to reduce childhood obesity is outlined in Section 3. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in collaboration with various entities, will develop a national strategy to reduce childhood obesity in the United States. The strategy aims to decrease obesity rates by 10% by 2011, address short- and long-term solutions, and overcome obstacles through effective partnerships. The national strategy to reduce childhood obesity in the United States includes measures to identify and overcome obstacles to achieving the goal. Grants are provided to local educational agencies for wellness policies and anti-obesity initiatives. The Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention provides grants to local educational agencies to reduce childhood obesity through wellness policies and anti-obesity initiatives, including improving food nutrition, incorporating nutrition education, increasing physical activity, and other measures for health improvement. The Director provides grants to local educational agencies to improve children's health and wellness. Local agencies must contribute 25% of the costs and submit an application with an annual accountability report on reducing childhood obesity. The Director provides grants to local educational agencies to improve children's health and wellness, with progress made in reducing childhood obesity using grant funds. Authorization of $20,000,000 for fiscal years 2008 through 2011 is available for this purpose. Evaluation of programs for preventing obesity in children and adolescents is addressed in Section 5. The Director will evaluate existing programs to prevent obesity in children and adolescents, assessing effectiveness, contributing factors, and feasibility of replication. A report on the evaluation results must be submitted to Congress within 18 months of the Act's enactment. Authorization of Appropriations: $5,000,000 authorized for fiscal years 2008 through 2011 to carry out the evaluation under this section. SEC. 6. HEALTHY LIVING AND WELLNESS COORDINATING COUNCILS. The Director will provide grants to reduce childhood obesity by establishing healthy living councils and supporting regional workshops. Grant recipients must use funds to expand council activities and organize workshops for educators and healthcare providers. The text discusses the establishment of healthy living councils to reduce childhood obesity in schools. These councils are composed of educators, administrators, healthcare providers, and other relevant parties. Grant recipients are required to cover at least 25% of the costs with non-Federal funds. Annual Accountability Report required for grant recipients to show progress in promoting healthy living and reducing obesity in schools. Authorization of $10,000,000 for fiscal years 2008 through 2011. SEC. 7. DEFINITIONS. The term "Director" refers to the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The term "local educational agency" is defined as in section 9101 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965.
